moves.1. Nf3 Nf6: I always mirror my opponent's nf3 with my nf6 and wait for white to decide the center.
moves.2. g3 g6: I don't like to commit to g6 when white hasn't committed to a queen pawn opening, but I decide to mirror white to take them into less familiar territory.
moves.3. d4: and that works out as g6 - bg6 is my main defense in the queens pawn game.
moves.3... d5 4. Bg2 Bg7 5. O-O O-O 6. c3 c6 7: and here, 16 automatic moves in, is the moment when I must stop copying to prevent hanging my queen.
moves.16... Ne5: Not entirely sure why I choose this over bxc6, but I may of felt c6 was a dead cause and re positioning the knight would be a better option.
moves.17. cxd4 Ng4: Down 2 pawns for the position of an odd placed 4th rank knight doesn't seem worth it.
moves.18. Rac1 Rac8 19. Nf3 Rfd8 20. h3 Nf6 21: I didn't see the fork now available at e3.
moves.23... bxc6: so I choose a lousy pawn.
moves.24. h4: but white didn't see it either, so I got my second chance.
I panicked under the pressure and captured the pawn out of order.
moves.29. Rxb2: Everything after this leads to a draw, but taught me that blunders occur in top levels just the same.
